awd_titl_txt: Deformation of Metals under High Pressure: Multiscale Stress Fields, Plasticity, and Phase Transformations
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract:

Processes that involve high pressures and plastic deformations are quite common in material synthesis and technologies, e.g. in high-pressure torsion (or twisting). The main objective of these technologies is to produce high-pressure phases and nanostructures that possess unique physical properties important for engineering applications. However, an understanding of the physical mechanisms and ways to characterize and control simultaneous evolution of plastic deformations, phase transformations, and microstructure under high pressure is lacking. The goal of the project is to conduct the first coupled experimental, theoretical, and computational multiscale study of non-uniform stresses and strains, plastic flow, and phase transformations in several technically-important metals under high pressure and shear deformation. The experimental study will be performed in a rotational diamond anvil cell, a unique device in which material is compressed by two diamond anvils to high pressure and then twisted. The transparency of the diamonds allows for measurements of strains and study of various phase transformations directly in the loaded sample. The experimental study will be combined with advanced multiscale modeling, enabling extraction of all deformational and transformational material properties at high pressure. New science produced in the project is expected to impact existing and future technologies for synthesis of the nanograined high-pressure phases. Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the proposed work, two graduate and two undergraduate students will be trained to learn, develop, and apply cutting-edge experimental and computational techniques to a variety of complex systems.


Technical abstract:

Processes involving high pressures and plastic deformations are quite common in material synthesis and technologies, in nature (e.g. in geophysics), and in physical experiments. High pressure usually causes phase transformations in solids and plastic straining significantly changes the microstructure, thermodynamics, and kinetics of phase transformations. However, an understanding of the physical mechanisms and ways to characterize simultaneous evolution of dislocations and phase transformations under high pressure is lacking. The goal of the project is to conduct the first coupled experimental, theoretical, and computational multiscale study of stress and strain fields, dislocational plasticity, and strain-induced phase transformations in Zr, Fe, Ce, and CeP under high pressure and shear deformation. The experimental study will be performed in a rotational diamond anvil cell, a unique device in which material is compressed to high pressure and then twisted, while providing an opportunity for in situ measurements and study of various phase transformations and strains. Molecular dynamics and a nanoscale phase field approach will be used to model stress-field and nucleation at defects, coupled to the synchrotron X-ray microdiffraction measurements. The kinetics of strain-controlled phase transformations will be determined in terms of volume fraction of phases. At the macroscale, the evolution of the fields of the stress tensor, displacements, plastic strain, and the volume fraction of high-pressure phases within the entire sample in a rotational diamond anvil cell will be measured and simulated. As a result, all deformational and transformational material properties will be determined at high pressure. The hypothesis that the pure volumetric phase transformations in Ce and CeP are affected by plastic shear will be checked.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to conduct the first coupled experimental, theoretical, and computational multiscale study of strain-induced phase transformations (PTs) and stress- and strain-tensor fields in Zr, Fe, and CeP under high pressure and large plastic deformation under compression in a diamond anvil cell (DAC) and torsion in rotational DAC (RDAC).

Intellectual Merit:

In the first in situ study on any metal, we found that if α-Zr, low-pressure Zr phase, is severely plastically pre-deformed (e.g., by multiple rolling) until steady (maximum) hardness is reached (corresponding to steady crystallite (grain) size d and dislocation density ), then high-pressure studies are tremendously simplified, and several discoveries have been made.

1. The minimum pressure for strain-induced α-ω PT 1.36 GPa (4.5 times lower than under hydrostatic loading and 2.6 times lower than the phase equilibrium pressure) is independent of the path  in RDAC and plastic strain before PT.  This means that the physics of strain-induced PTs under compression in DAC and torsion in RDAC do not differ fundamentally, and strain-induced PTs can be studied in DAC as well. Of course, RDAC has a strong advantage in allowing various controllable pressure-shear loading programs, particularly at constant pressure.

2. We introduced rough diamond anvils (rough-DA), whose culet is roughly polished to increase friction to the maximum possible, equal to the yield strength in shear. This allowed us to robustly determine the pressure-dependence of the yield strength in shear for ω-Zr. Rough-DA drastically change the plastic flow, microstructure, and PTs. Rough-DA allowed us to solve several other basic problems and bring up discoveries described below.

3. We found new fundamental rules under severe plastic straining of Zr in DAC at high pressure:

(a)    The minimum pressure for plastic strain-induced α-ω PT in Zr, the yield strength (yield surface) of ω-Zr, crystallite size, and dislocation density are getting steady and independent of the plastic strain tensor and its entire path!

(b)   ω-Zr behaves like perfectly plastic, isotropic, and strain path-independent immediately after PT.

(c)    Crystallite size and dislocation density in ω-Zr during PT depend solely on the volume fraction of ω-Zr and are independent of pressure, plastic strain tensor and its path.  

(d)   The kinetics of strain-induced PT depends not only on plastic strain but also on time, in contrast to all previous publications. That means that stress-induced PT at fixed strain occurs simultaneously with plastic strain-induced PTs, and new experimental and theoretical treatments are necessary.

(e)    Rough-DA produce a different steady state and microstructures than the traditional diamonds, for both α- and ω-Zr, with smaller crystallite size (down to 50 nm), two times smaller PT pressure (i.e., by a factor of 9 lower than for hydrostatic loading), and larger dislocation density.

(f)  The minimum pressure for plastic strain-induced α-ω PT in Zr reduces with reducing grain size down to a steady state.

4. We developed a coupled analytical-computational-experimental approach to determine material deformational and transformational properties and all (including stress and plastic strain tensor) fields in DAC, which will revolutionize the high-pressure field.

5. We obtained and quantified unique continuous (i.e., without coexistence of two different lattices) second-order iso-structural fcc-fcc electronic in plastically pre-deformed CeP under plastic compression.

6. We developed new finite-strain phase field approaches for multivariant martensitic PTs with stress-dependent effective thresholds at the microscale, multiphase phase-field theory for PTs at the nanoscale and for fracture with surface stresses, and interaction of fracture and PTs.

7. We elucidated and quantified the effect of a single dislocation and dislocation pileup on PTs using molecular dynamics, nano- and microscale phase field, and concurrent atomistic-continuum approaches.

8. We obtained analytical 3D solutions for strain-induced PT, transformation-induced plasticity, self-blown-up deformation-transformation-heating in shear band than was applied to explain the main puzzles in deep-focus earthquakes and can be applied to various material system and phenomena. 

Broad Impacts: Three PhD students have graduated. Five post-docs, three other PhD students, and seven undergraduate US students (four of whom are female and one under-represented) have worked on this project.  The PI developed and taught a new research-oriented graduate class "High-pressure mechanics and phase transformations." The PI has significantly updated his research-oriented graduate classes "Phase Transformations in Elastic Materials," "Phase Transformations and Plasticity," "Micromechanics of structural changes in materials," and "Continuum Mechanochemistry." All classes included many results obtained in this project and acquaintance with PI's high pressure-shear lab. Results of the project have been disseminated through 27 publications in highly-ranked journals (including 2 papers in Science, 2 in Nature Communications, 9 in Acta Materials, as well as, PRL, npj Computational Materials, PRB, Nanoscale, Int. J. Plasticity, J. Mech. Phys. Solids, Int. J. Eng. Sci., etc.; two invited review papers), 57 conference talks (including one plenary lecture and 18 keynote and invited talks), and 6 invited seminars. The PI co-organized two symposia on the topic of the project.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2022
Modified by: Valery I Levitas

Images (1 of )
  • Experiments showing that crystallite size and dislocation density in Zr are getting pressure-, strain- and strain-path-independent before and after phase transformation, and depend solely on the volume fractions of phases during transformation. Pressure dependence of yield strength is found.
    Feng Lin and Valery Levitas
    Creative Commons
    Valery I Levitas
    Results of in situ experiments on compression of Zr in diamond anvil cell with rough diamonds
  • Coupled evolution of dislocations, martensite, M, and two martensitic variants, M1 and M2 (red) during compression and shear. Dislocation pileups significantly reduce phase transformation pressure in comparison with hydrostatic loading.
    Valery Levitas and Ehsan Esfahani
    Creative Commons
    Valery I Levitas
    Scale-free phase field modeling of dislocation-induced phase transformation in a polycrystal under compression and shear.
  • Left: Distributions of pressure and concentration of omega-Zr. Right: Pressure p - plastic strain q loading paths and correspondence of analytical and experimental transformation kinetics, which is independent of the loading path. Minimum transformation pressure is independent of q & strain path.
    Krishan KUmar Pandey and Valery Levitas
    Valery I Levitas
    Distributions of pressure in phases and volume fractions of omega-Zr and kinetics of strain-induced alpha-omega transformation under compression and torsion in rotational diamond anvil cell.
  • Top: Two lower experimental pressure distributions were used for calibration of the pressure-dependence of the yield strength and friction coefficient. Two upper curves and 4 thickness profiles we used for verification. Bottom: Calculated field of stress and plastic strain tensors, rotations, etc.
    Valery Levitas and Mehdi Kamrani
    Creative Commons
    Valery I Levitas
    Calibration and verification of the elastoplastic model for W up to 400 GPa.
  • Multivariant martensitic microstructure in a cube (left), twinned martensite with splitted tips near habit plane (center), and martensite at the tip of the vertical propagating crack.
    Valery Levitas, Anup Basak, and Hossein Jafarzadeh
    Valery I Levitas
    Examples of coupled phase-field and mechanics simulations.
por.por_txt_cntn:
The goal of this project is to conduct the first coupled experimental, theoretical, and computational multiscale study of strain-induced phase transformations (PTs) and stress- and strain-tensor fields in Zr, Fe, and CeP under high pressure and large plastic deformation under compression in a diamond anvil cell (DAC) and torsion in rotational DAC (RDAC).
